title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: It's the no-bull performances that hold back the flood of banalities. Robbins and Freeman connect with the bruised souls of Andy and Red to create something undeniably powerful and moving.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Gripping...compelling.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Central to the film's success is a riveting, unfussy performance from Robbins. Freeman has the showier role, allowing him a grace and dignity that come naturally.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: There are times when The Shawshank Redemption comes dangerously close to sounding one of those "triumph of the spirit" notes. But most of it is eloquently restrained. [23 Sept 1994, p.C3]

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: [Darabont] makes you feel the maddening pace of prison time without letting his picture succumb to it.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: At times poignant, joyful, and terrifying, Shawshank Redemption is an altogether brilliant movie and the debut of an equally brilliant director.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Whitmore's Brooks is a brilliantly-realized character, and the scenes with him attempting to cope with life outside of Shawshank represents one of the film's most moving -- and effective -- sequences.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Some of "The Shawshank Redemption'' comes across as outrageously improbable. Yet the film keeps pulling you back with its sense of striving humanity slowly turning the tables against evil.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Shouldering a laconic-good-guy, neo- Gary Cooper role, Robbins never quite makes emotional contact with the audience.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
review: Speaking of jail, "Shawshank"-the-movie seems to last about half a life sentence. The story, chiefly about the 20-year friendship between Freeman and Robbins, becomes incarcerated in its own labyrinthine sentimentality.

title: The Godfather
review: Just about as great as a movie's ever gonna be... As for the storytellng, The Godfather is an intricately constructed gem that simultaneously kicks ass.

title: The Godfather
review: The picture is a series of mini-climaxes, all building to the devastating, definitive conclusion... It was carefully and painstakingly crafted. Every major character - and more than a few minor ones - is molded into a distinct, complex individual.

title: The Godfather
review: The wedding sequence... is a virtuoso stretch of filmmaking: Coppola brings his large cast onstage so artfully that we are drawn at once into the Godfather's world.

title: The Godfather
review: In scene after scene -- the long wedding sequence, John Marley's bloody discovery in his bed, Pacino nervously smoothing down his hair before a restaurant massacre, the godfather's collapse in a garden -- Coppola crafted an enduring, undisputed masterpiece. [21 Mar 1997, Daily Datebook, p.C3]

title: The Godfather
review: One of the most brutal and moving chronicles of American life ever designed within the limits of popular entertainment. [16 Mar 1972]

title: The Godfather
review: A great American picture, full of incredible images and lasting moments.

title: The Godfather
review: The Godfather traces the arc of this doomed idealism with a beauty that is still fresh.

title: The Godfather
review: Sharp, entertaining, and convincing--discursive, but with a sense of structure and control that Coppola hasn't achieved since.

title: The Godfather
review: Overflowing with life, rich with all the grand emotions and vital juices of existence, up to and including blood. And its deaths, like that of Hotspur in "Henry IV, Part I," continue to shock no matter how often we've watched them coming. [16 Mar 1997, Calendar, p.7]

title: The Godfather
review: Overlong at about 175 minutes (played without intermission), and occasionally confusing. While never so placid as to be boring, it is never so gripping as be superior screen drama.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: And with supporting roles from the likes of Diane Keaton, Robert Duvall and Lee Strasberg, to say nothing of Roger Corman and Harry Dean Stanton in bit parts, this is nothing short of magisterial.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: As the beginning of Part II echoes the opening of "The Godfather," so too does the end. Because of the manner in which circumstances are handled and considering the people involved, the impact here is more forceful. The tragic flaw has accomplished its poisonous, inevitable designs. Coppola punctuates both movies with a gut-twisting exclamation point.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: Cinematographer Willis superbly captures the turn-of-the-century period, applying a seriographic tint to flashback scenes for a softer, richer look than the sharp image of the ongoing contemporary story.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: This is quite simply one of the saddest movies ever made, a tale of loss, grief and absolute loneliness, an unflinching stare into the darkest moral abyss.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: The plotting is elliptical and the sweep intoxicates, but the contrast between De Niro’s meditative Vito and Pacino’s soul-starved eyes brings piercing focus to Coppola’s resonating study of corrupting power.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: Al Pacino again is outstanding as Michael Corleone, successor to crime family leadership.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: It is neither a very happy or driving picture. But it is intellectually daring and marks an important breakthrough in the growing up of the Hollywood film.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: Coppola is unable to draw all this together and make it work on the level of simple, absorbing narrative. The stunning text of "The Godfather" is replaced in Part II with prologues, epilogues, footnotes, and good intentions.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: Three hours and 20 minutes of Al Pacino suffering openly, Robert Duvall suffering silently, Diane Keaton suffering noisily, and (every so often) Robert De Niro suffering good-naturedly is almost too much, but Francis Ford Coppola pulls it off in grand style.

title: The Godfather: Part II
review: The only remarkable thing about Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather, Part II is the insistent manner in which it recalls how much better his original film was...Even if Part II were a lot more cohesive, revealing, and exciting than it is, it probably would have run the risk of appearing to be the self-parody it now seems.

title: The Dark Knight
review: Enthralling...An ambitious, full-bodied crime epic of gratifying scope and moral complexity, this is seriously brainy pop entertainment that satisfies every expectation raised by its hit predecessor and then some.

title: The Dark Knight
review: Bale again brilliantly personifies all the deep traumas and misgivings of Batman's alter ego, Bruce Wayne. A bit of Hamlet is in this Batman.

title: The Dark Knight
review: Beyond dark. It's as black -- and teeming and toxic -- as the mind of the Joker. "Batman Begins," the 2005 film that launched Nolan's series, was a mere five-finger exercise. This is the full symphony.

title: The Dark Knight
review: Christopher Nolan has provided movie-goers with the best superhero movie to-date, outclassing previous titles both mediocre and excellent, and giving this franchise its "The Empire Strikes Back."

title: The Dark Knight
review: At two hours and 32 minutes, this is almost too much movie, but it has a malicious, careening zest all its own. It's a ride for the gut AND the brain.

title: The Dark Knight
review: No fair giving away the mysteries of The Dark Knight. It's enough to marvel at the way Nolan -- a world-class filmmaker, be it "Memento," "Insomnia" or "The Prestige" -- brings pop escapism whisper-close to enduring art.

title: The Dark Knight
review: The Dark Knight is dark, all right: It's a luxurious nightmare disguised in a superhero costume, and it's proof that popcorn entertainments don't have to talk down to their audiences in order to satisfy them. The bar for comic-book film adaptations has been permanently raised.

title: The Dark Knight
review: You may emerge more exhausted than elated. Nolan wants to prove that a superhero movie needn't be disposable, effects-ridden junk food, and you have to admire his ambition. But this is Batman, not "Hamlet." Call me shallow, but I wish it were a little more fun.

title: The Dark Knight
review: The novelty wears off and the lack of imagination, visual and otherwise, turns into a drag. The Dark Knight is noisy, jumbled, and sadistic.

title: The Dark Knight
review: The Dark Knight is hardly routine--it has a kicky sadism in scene after scene, which keeps you on edge and sends you out onto the street with post-movie stress disorder.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: The movie plays like a textbook for directors interested in how lens choices affect mood.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: A penetrating, sensitive, and sometimes shocking dissection of the hearts and minds of men who obviously are something less than gods. It makes for taut, absorbing, and compelling drama that reaches far beyond the close confines of its jury room setting.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: What's most interesting about the intense deliberations that ensue, specifically when a piece of seemingly indisputable evidence is brought back into question, is how a fresh angle and perspective, usually born from Juror 8's critical thinking, can permanently alter the tone of the discussion.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: Few film directors can resist the urge to "open out" a story, to broaden the view and bring in as wide a variety of sets and locations as the narrative - and budget - will allow. The genius of Sidney Lumet's astonishingly powerful 12 Angry Men is that he does exactly the opposite: he takes an already small, claustrophobic space - a jury room - and makes it even more confined.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: Too few films take on the art of arguing as a subject; we could certainly use more of them, but until then, Lumet’s window into strained civic duty will continue to serve mightily.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: Sidney Lumet's dazzling debut, based on Reginald Rose's teleplay, delivers a masterclass in the pure dynamism of acting, as Henry Fonda's reasonable doubt gradually sways the 11 other jurors from their various prejudices.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: Perhaps the motivations of each juror are introduced too quickly and are repeated too often before each changes his vote. However, the film leaves a tremendous impact.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: What really transforms the piece from a rather talky demonstration that a man is innocent until proven guilty, is the consistently taut, sweltering atmosphere, created largely by Boris Kaufman's excellent camerawork. The result, however devoid of action, is a strangely realistic thriller.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: The stakes of those deliberations are so high, the personalities of the jurors so forceful, and the arguments so pregnant with importance that there is no instance in which boredom threatens.

title: 12 Angry Men
review: Mechanically written, but within its own middlebrow limitations, it delivers the goods.

title: Schindler's List
review: What is surprising is how well Spielberg captures the horror, moving his camera with the fury of a combat photographer on the run. [17 Dec 1993]

title: Schindler's List
review: The other key part is Schindler's Jewish accountant, played with self-effacing brilliance by Ben Kingsley, who gives the movie just the touch of warmth and sanity it needs.

title: Schindler's List
review: Director Steven Spielberg has achieved something close to the impossible--a morally serious, aesthetically stunning historical epic that is nonetheless readily accessible to a mass audience.

title: Schindler's List
review: What is most amazing about this film is how completely Spielberg serves his story. The movie is brilliantly acted, written, directed and seen. Individual scenes are masterpieces of art direction, cinematography, special effects, crowd control.

title: Schindler's List
review: Spielberg restages the Holocaust with an existential vividness unprecedented in any nondocumentary film: He makes us feel as if we're living right inside the 20th century's darkest-and most defining-episode.

title: Schindler's List
review: Epic cinema, tragic drama, it is also an act of remembrance and conscience that ultimately transcends the ordinary critical categories.

title: Schindler's List
review: Evinces an artistic rigor and unsentimental intelligence unlike anything the world's most successful filmmaker has demonstrated before.

title: Schindler's List
review: The movie's ending at the train station and the modern-day epilogue feel protracted and indulgent...Apart from the ending though, this is Spielberg's most articulate movie ever.

title: Schindler's List
review: A powerful and affecting piece of work.

title: Schindler's List
review: Spielberg does an uncommonly good job both of holding our interest over 185 minutes and of showing more of the nuts and bolts of the Holocaust than we usually get from fiction films. Despite some characteristic simplifications, he's generally scrupulous about both his source and the historical record.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: The conclusion of Peter Jackson's masterwork is passionate and literate, detailed and expansive, and it's conceived with a risk-taking flair for old-fashioned movie magic at its most precious.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: An epic success and a history-making production that finishes with a masterfully entertaining final installment.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: The second installment was better than the first, and this one is best of all. It has spectacular action scenes and imaginary creatures, and it’s by far the most moving chapter. The performances have deepened.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: The second half of the film elevates all the story elements to Beethovenian crescendo. Here is an epic with literature's depth and opera's splendor -- and one that could be achieved only in movies. What could be more terrific?

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: Represents that filmmaking rarity -- a third part of a trilogy that is decisively the best of the lot. With epic conflict, staggering battles, striking landscapes and effects, and resolved character arcs all leading to a dramatic conclusion to more than nine hours of masterful storytelling.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: Those who have walked beside these heroes every step of the way on such a long journey deserve the emotional pay-off as well as the action peaks, and they will be genuinely touched as the final credits roll.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: Labeling this as a "movie" is almost an injustice. This is an experience of epic scope and grandeur, amazing emotional power, and relentless momentum.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: Jackson is rare among the makers of epic movies in that he knows how to do the small stuff, too. The Return of the King has “heart”--how else could it pump out all that blood?

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: The most emotionally satisfying because, in addition to having both more intimate drama and more spectacular battles, it resolves all of the issues raised before.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
review: A majestic conclusion to a nine-plus-hours epic that stirs the heart, mind and soul as few films ever have.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: Pulp Fiction isn't just funny. It's outrageously funny. [14 Oct 1994]

title: Pulp Fiction
review: For a brutal black comedy about L.A. hitmen, Pulp Fiction bursts out of its binding with loopy delights. [14 Oct 1994]

title: Pulp Fiction
review: It is an exhilaration from beginning to end. It's the movie equivalent of that rare sort of novel where you find yourself checking to see how many pages are left and hoping there are more, not fewer.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: Like "Citizen Kane," Pulp Fiction is constructed in such a nonlinear way that you could see it a dozen times and not be able to remember what comes next.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: With this film, every layer that you peel away leads to something deeper and richer. Tarantino makes pictures for movie-lovers, and Pulp Fiction is a near-masterpiece.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: The new King Kong of crime movies...Ferocious fun without a trace of caution, complacency or political correctness to inhibit its 154 deliciously lurid minutes.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: Pulp Fiction is at least three movies rolled into one, and they're all scintillating.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: A spectacularly entertaining piece of pop culture, Pulp Fiction is the "American Graffiti" of violent crime pictures.

title: Pulp Fiction
review: The first masterwork of the post-modern pop culture generation...gets better with every viewing, and like good rock n' roll, needs to be played loud!

title: Pulp Fiction
review: But the way that this picture has been so widely ravened up and drooled over verges on the disgusting. Pulp Fiction nourishes, abets, cultural slumming. [14 Nov 1994]

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: Though ordained from the beginning, the three-way showdown that climaxes the film is tense and thoroughly astonishing.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: An improbable masterpiece -- a bizarre mixture of grandly operatic visuals, grim brutality and sordid violence that keeps wrenching you from one extreme to the other.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: There are two kinds of people, my friend. Those who love Sergio Leone's The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, and those who resist the machismo and gallows humor of what is arguably the definitive spaghetti western.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: Gorgeously stoic art film.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: A massive, many-faceted film that continues to hold up, viewing after viewing.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: All told, and in giant widescreen, it's only blood-red adolescent fun, but it blooms like Douglas Sirk with a Gatling gun compared to the teenage demographic's current fare. Matrix, schmatrix: This is the season's supreme party movie.

title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
review: A curious amalgam of the visually striking, the dramatically feeble and the offensively sadistic.

title: Fight Club
review: Delivers a sucker punch to the audience and then pulls the rug out from under it. It is sensational. It is also grimly funny.

title: Fight Club
review: Fight Club -- cue the blurb machine -- is a knockout.

title: Fight Club
review: The sardonic, testosterone-fueled science fiction of Fight Club touches a raw nerve.

title: Fight Club
review: As a piece of storytelling, Fight Club is a bit of a dud: It's a good 15 minutes too long, and the tension doesn't build the way you wish it would.

title: Fight Club
review: A provocative experience that lights you up even as it brutalizes you. And I don't even like Brad Pitt very much.

title: Fight Club
review: Keeps filmgoers wondering what will happen next even as they are repulsed by what's happening in front of them.

title: Fight Club
review: It's fun to talk about...but the price you pay is enduring its excesses and pummeled-home thematic points.

title: Fight Club
review: This exercise in mainstream masochism, macho posturing, and designer-grunge fascism is borderline ridiculous. But it also happens to be David Fincher's richest movie.

title: Fight Club
review: But the second act is pandering and the third is trickery, and whatever Fincher thinks the message is, that's not what most audience members will get.

title: Fight Club
review: But imagination and energy are often not enough. On balance, this is the dumbest of the entries in Hollywood's anti-consumerist new wave.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: I see it as nearly perfect: It's one of the best fantasy pictures ever made.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: An extraordinary work, grandly conceived, brilliantly executed and wildly entertaining. It's a hobbit's dream, a wizard's delight. And, of course, it's only the beginning.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: Against all odds in an era of machine-made spectaculars, Mr. Jackson and his collaborators have created a film epic that lives and breathes.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: The Movie Works. It has real passion, real emotion, real terror, and a tactile sense of evil that is missing in that other current movie dealing with wizards, wonders and wickedness.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: So consistently involving because the excellent cast delivers their lines with the kind of utter conviction not seen in this kind of movie since the first "Star Wars."

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: The film's single downside is a certain nagging sense of deja vu: the fact that so many of the elements of the story -- the dark force, the all-empowering object, etc. -- have been usurped over the years (by "Star Wars" and others) that you feel as if you've been down this road many, many times before.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: The film succeeds as massive, astonishing entertainment; verily, enthralling us is its chief goal.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: Jackson's dazzling vision turns the story into a real movie-movie -- one that, unlike too many fantasy films today, is genuinely transporting.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: Above all, Jackson evokes an almost palpable sense of the will to power trapped within the ring. Without this evocation of the ring's insidious ability to sniff out the potential for corruption and capitalize on it, the entire enterprise would be precious drivel.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
review: But moving across this tableau is Frodo and his gang, and here the trouble lies...Not a one seems believable as conveyed by Wood, who forever looks to be on the brink of a good sob. Likewise, his hobbit sidekick Samwise Gamgee (Sean Astin) is a real wuss.

title: Forrest Gump
review: Passionate and magical, Forrest Gump is a tonic for the weary of spirit.

title: Forrest Gump
review: Manages the difficult feat of being an intimate, even delicate tale played with an appealingly light touch against an epic backdrop.

title: Forrest Gump
review: The results are skillful, highly affecting, and ultimately more than a little pernicious.

title: Forrest Gump
review: A remarkable balance of sentimentality and harshness, darkness and light.

title: Forrest Gump
review: Doesn't sound like a very prepossessing title, but prepare to be taken aback by "what's in a name." [6 July 1994, Life, p.1D]

title: Forrest Gump
review: The film's technical brilliance and sentimental kick seduced many viewers unsuspecting of its polemical intent.

title: Forrest Gump
review: It's most successful when it is being off-center, a state of grace it doesn't quite have the nerve to maintain. [6 July 1994, Calendar, p. F-1]

title: Forrest Gump
review: Has the elements of an emotionally gripping story. Yet is feels less like a romance than like a coffee-table book celebrating the magic of special effect. [6 July 1994, p. C9]

title: Forrest Gump
review: Clearly a great event, Forrest Gump is not, however, a great film. It has the form of an epic without real depth or resonance; the trappings of satire without a coherent attitude; and the semblance of historical revisionism without a critical sensibility.

title: Forrest Gump
review: It is also glib, shallow, and monotonous, a movie that spends so much time sanctifying its hero that, despite his "innocence," he ends up seeming about as vulnerable as Superman.

title: Inception
review: In terms of sheer originality, ambition and achievement, Inception is the movie of the summer, the movie of the year and the movie of our dreams.

title: Inception
review: If Inception is a metaphysical puzzle, it's also a metaphorical one: It's hard not to draw connections between Cobb's dream-weaving and Nolan's filmmaking -- an activity devoted to constructing a simulacrum of reality, intended to seduce us, mess with our heads and leave a lasting impression. Mission accomplished.

title: Inception
review: With physics-defying, thunderous action, heart-wringing emotion and an astonishing performance from DiCaprio, Nolan delivers another true original: welcome to an undiscovered country.

title: Inception
review: In a summer of remakes, reboots and sequels comes Inception, easily the most original movie idea in ages.

title: Inception
review: In this wildly ingen­ious chess game, grandmaster Nolan plants ideas in our heads that disturb and dazzle. The result is a knockout. But be warned: Inception dreams big. How cool is that?

title: Inception
review: As engrossing and logic-resistant as the state of dreaming it seeks to replicate, Christopher Nolan's audacious new creation demands further study to fully absorb the multiple, simultaneous stories Nolan finagles into one narrative experience.

title: Inception
review: Inception, though, is no "Avatar"--instead, it’s the movie that many wanted "Avatar" to be. In a roaringly fast first hour, we’re introduced to a new technology that allows for the bodily invasion of another person’s dreamworld.

title: Inception
review: Inception is an elegant, portentous ride, though I’m not sure Nolan is any closer to visualizing the real (dream) deal than Hitchcock was.

title: Inception
review: Inception manages to be clunky and confusing on four separate levels of reality.

title: Inception
review: It's obvious that Nolan either can't articulate or doesn't believe in a distinction between living feelings and dreams--and his barren Inception doesn't capture much of either.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The best of three Star Wars films, and the most thought-provoking. After the space opera cheerfulness of the original film, this one plunges into darkness and even despair, and surrenders more completely to the underlying mystery of the story. It is because of the emotions stirred in Empire that the entire series takes on a mythic quality that resonates back to the first and ahead to the third. This is the heart.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The storyline is more interesting and ambitious, the characters -- little more than appealing types in the original -- are allowed to grow and develop, the special effects are more mature, and the tone is deliciously dark and downbeat. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The balance between action and mysticism in The Empire Strikes Back provides fascinating energy. It's as if the kids are given one set of delights, the bravado of battles and elaborate warships zooming through exotic space, and adults are given another, a layered explanation of what it all means in the grand scheme of things. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: It balances bloodshed with charm, spectacle with childlike glee. It's a near flawless movie of its kind.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: Technical virtuosity and entertainment ingenuity.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: It was incredible to see what is arguably the best of the Star Wars films, on the big screen again. However, I do not believe that any of the minor changes make the film any better. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: This is the bluest film you'll ever see. The haunting color resounds throughout Empire like a sustained, melancholy chord...Empire is essential viewing for lovers of science fiction. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: A darker, richer, and more elaborate film than the original; it suffers most from being just what it is: a middle chapter with no real ending. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: The Empire Strikes Back is not a truly terrible movie. It's a nice movie. It's not, by any means, as nice as "Star Wars." It's not as fresh and funny and surprising and witty, but it is nice and inoffensive and, in a way that no one associated with it need be ashamed of, it's also silly.

title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back
review: Mainly it's marking time: the characters take a definite backseat to the special effects, and much of the action seems gratuitous, leading nowhere.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: The miracle is that 'The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers is better: tighter, smarter, funnier.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: Towers, while not quite so varied as Fellowship in its moods and settings, has a grave gusto that energizes every moment...a thrilling work of film craft.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: The Two Towers moves faster, covers more ground, has more action and -- with the introduction of the marvelous character Gollum -- packs some much-appreciated laughs.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: Never has a film so strongly been a product of a director's respect for its source. Mr. Jackson uses all his talents in the service of that reverence, creating a rare perfect mating of filmmaker and material.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: The year's greatest adventure, and Jackson's limited but enthusiastic adaptation has made literature literal without killing its soul.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: Has a sharper narrative focus and a livelier sense of forward movement than did the more episodic "Fellowship."

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: God forbid this should ever play on an IMAX screen -- the concussive soundtrack and relentless visuals would likely strike viewers deaf and blind (but what a way to go!). Simply breathtaking.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: Epic battles, spectacular effects and multiple story lines make The Two Towers a most excellent middle chapter in The Lord of the Rings film trilogy.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: A rousing adventure, a skillful marriage of special effects and computer animation, and it contains sequences of breathtaking beauty. It also gives us, in a character named the Gollum, one of the most engaging and convincing CGI creatures I've seen.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
review: This second installment is heavy on battle sequences, which will thrill some viewers more than others.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Too many classic set pieces to mention but keep your ears cocked for that immortal line "Mmmm, Juicy Fruit." Certified brilliance.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: A masterpiece. (9 Jan 1998, p.3D)

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Brilliant cinema theatre.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Playing the mental-hospital firebrand who rebels against monstrous Nurse Ratched (Louise Fletcher), Nicholson seduces in an anti-establishment classic with a gut-punch exit.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Here is the bruised-plum role that put Jack Nicholson into the biggest of big leagues.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: With One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, Forman takes his rightful place as one of our most creative young directors. His casting is inspired, his sense of milieu is assured, and he could probably wring Academy Award performances from a stone.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: Jarring and electrifying drama.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: So good in so many of its parts that there's a temptation to forgive it when it goes wrong. But it does go wrong, insisting on making larger points than its story really should carry, so that at the end, the human qualities of the characters get lost in the significance of it all. And yet there are those moments of brilliance.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: This slick and entertaining 1975 film of Ken Kesey's cult novel will inevitably disappoint admirers of director Milos Forman's earlier work.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review: A comedy that can't quite support its tragic conclusion, which is too schematic to be honestly moving, but it is acted with such a sense of life that one responds to its demonstration of humanity if not to its programmed metaphors.

title: Goodfellas
review: All of the performances are first-rate; Pesci stands out, though, with his seemingly unscripted manner. GoodFellas is easily one of the year's best films. [21 September 1990, Friday, p.C]

title: Goodfellas
review: Director Martin Scorsese's spectacular, irreverent picture.

title: Goodfellas
review: Stunningly acted. [21 September 1990, The Arts, p.12]

title: Goodfellas
review: No finer film has ever been made about organized crime - not even "The Godfather."

title: Goodfellas
review: Ferocious brutality is presented without commentary or judgment, yet with unmistakable moral understanding and vision. [21 September 1990, Daily Notebook p.E-1]

title: Goodfellas
review: One of Martin Scorsese's most brutal but stunning movies, an incredible, relentless experience about the singleminded pursuit of crime.

title: Goodfellas
review: An appalling masterpiece.

title: Goodfellas
review: Martin Scorsese scores again with his gritty, kinetic adaptation of Nicolas Pileggi's best-selling "Wiseguy."

title: Goodfellas
review: Simultaneously fascinating and repellent, Goodfellas is Martin Scorsese's colorful but dramatically unsatisfying inside look at Mafia life in 1955-1980 New York City.

title: Goodfellas
review: Scorsese's style, fierce as it is, doesn't accomplish what he clearly expected of it. Often, in many arts, fresh treatment can redeem familiar subjects, but it doesn't happen here. [Oct 22, 1990]

title: The Matrix
review: The Matrix slams you back in your chair, pops open your eyes and leaves your jaw hanging slack in amazement.

title: The Matrix
review: The Wachowskis do it so playfully well, keeping The Matrix's potentially confusing plot intelligible, intelligent, and suspenseful, that it doesn't matter.

title: The Matrix
review: Bill Pope's swooping, noir-inflected cinematography is wonderfully complemented by Owen Paterson's inventive production design, a great soundtrack and the best fight choreography this side of Hong Kong. And even if this isn't "Blade Runner," it is very cool shit.

title: The Matrix
review: Kinetic, atmospheric, visually stunning, and mind-bending.

title: The Matrix
review: There's a kind of liberating, almost transforming energy in this film; it lights you up and sends you out all giddy with silliness.

title: The Matrix
review: Doesn't just raise the bar on sci-fi and action films, it rips that sucker off and sends it spiraling into the sun.

title: The Matrix
review: The plot switches gears every time it threatens to run out of energy, which keeps the show as lively as it is preposterous.

title: The Matrix
review: Aerves up so much visual wizardry and thought-provoking ideas that even the inevitable Silver touch -- a finale with more bullets than the opening of "Saving Private Ryan" -- can't destroy the magic.

title: The Matrix
review: It may bore you to death or blow your mind -- and it's long and convoluted enough to do both -- but it holds nothing back.

title: The Matrix
review: There's not much humor to keep it all life-size, and by the final stretch it's become bloated, mechanical, and tiresome.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: I have to admit, in all its surreal grandiosity, in all its delirious absurdity, there is a huge sugar rush of excitement to this mighty finale, finally interchanging with euphoric emotion and allowing us to say poignant farewells.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: Avengers: Endgame is easily the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s most ambitious, emotional, and affecting film to date, somehow managing to tie up more than a decade of storytelling in a confident (and mostly coherent) climax - a hurdle that many other blockbuster franchises have stumbled over in their final runs.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: What's best about Markus and McFeely's script is that they understand the characters.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: If the Marvel superhero movies on the whole are your favorite band’s individual albums, Avengers: Endgame is the triple-disc greatest-hits package with the really awesome cover and a slew of familiar, comforting gems inside.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: The movie largely delivers, splashing its ambitious three-hour narrative across a sprawling canvas of characters, eras, and not-quite-insurmountable challenges.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: No matter what comes next from Marvel Studios, this Avengers is a gargantuan love letter to the equally enormous mythology that Stan Lee, Jack Kirby, Steve Ditko and the rest of their collaborators built — and to the generations of readers and moviegoers who truly believe in it.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: Avengers: Endgame has almost nothing on its mind but crossing the Ts and dotting the Is of a far-flung superhero saga, but to anyone with even a minor emotional stake in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it has all the fleeting satisfaction of a shot of whipped cream delivered directly from the spray can.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: It’s the time travel conceit that keeps “Endgame” hopping, and the trial-and-error sequences recall some of the best parts of the first “Iron Man” 11 years back.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: While constantly eventful and a feast for the eyes, it's also notably more somber than its predecessors. But just when it might seem about to become too grim, Robert Downey Jr. rides to the rescue with an inspired serio-comic performance that reminds you how good he can be.

title: Avengers: Endgame
review: Even if I could muster the strength to defy studio marching orders on plot details, there is no point. There is little in Endgame that is worth spoiling, given how its core is spoiled rotten to begin with.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: Moves like hot mercury, and it draws a viewer so thoroughly into its world that real life can seem thick and dull when the lights come up.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: Much imitated, still unsurpassed. By critical consensus one of the best movies ever made, The Seven Samurai covers so much emotional, historical, and cinematic ground that that it demands to be viewed over and over again.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: The legendary Mifune leads a superb cast, and Kurosawa's kinetic camera keeps the adventure sizzling with energy and wit from start to finish.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: It's impossible to imagine how the action genre would have developed without Akira Kurosawa's watershed 1954 movie Seven Samurai.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: Rich in detail, vivid in characterization, leisurely in exposition, this 207-minute epic is bravura filmmaking -- a brilliant yet facile synthesis of Hollywood pictorialism, Soviet montage, and Japanese theatricality that could be a B western transposed to Mars.

title: Shichinin no samurai
review: On that simple framework and familiar story line, director Kurosawa has plastered a wealth of rich detail, which brilliantly illuminates his characters and the kind of action in which they are involved. He has loaded his film with unusual and exciting physical incidents and made the whole thing graphic in a hard, realistic western style.

title: Se7en
review: It's intriguing, appalling, savvy, nasty, grossly unsettling -- you may not like what you see, but you'll definitely be affected by the sight.

title: Se7en
review: A dark, grisly, horrifying and intelligent thriller.

title: Se7en
review: This homicide thriller has a tantalizingly morbid atmosphere of unease.

title: Se7en
review: While Seven lacks the cleverness of the superior "Usual Suspects," it's strong enough to hold its own against most other thrillers.

title: Se7en
review: It's not the identity of the killer that gives Seven its kick -- it's the way Fincher raises mystery to the level of moral provocation.

title: Se7en
review: Director David Fincher shovels on more gloom than even the serial killer genre can sustain in the murkily moody, but self-defeating, Seven.

title: Se7en
review: It is very tiresome peering through the gloom trying to catch a glimpse of something interesting, then having to avert one's eyes when it turns out to be just another brutally tormented body.

title: Se7en
review: Watching Seven is like cracking open a safe, only to find it crawling with eels

title: Se7en
review: A style so chic, studied and murky it resembles a cross between a Nike commercial and a bad Polish art film.

title: Se7en
review: Not even bags of body parts, a bitten-off tongue or a man forced to cut off a pound of his own flesh keep it from being dull. [22 September 1995, p. C18]

title: Cidade de Deus
review: The film is seductive, disturbing, enthralling -- a trip to hell that gives the passengers a great ride.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: Like a bomb exploding in a fireworks factory: It's fierce and shocking and dazzling and wonderful.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: A marvelous achievement that refuses to avert its gaze from the poetry and the insane savagery of the hopeless.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: As the movie's frenetic visual rhythms and mood swings synchronize with the zany, adrenaline-fueled impulsiveness of its lost youth on the rampage, you may find yourself getting lost in this teeming netherworld.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: It takes a strong stomach to sit through its two-plus hours of non-stop brutality (much of it involving very small children).

title: Cidade de Deus
review: A potent and unexpected mixture of authenticity and flash -- even if this is what happened on the ground, making it worth our time on screen is just beyond the contortionist abilities of even this most acrobatic of films.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: Meirelles's picture is so keen to brandish its social wrath, and its spirits are so rampagingly high, that the bruises it inflicts barely last a night. [20 January 2003, p. 94]

title: Cidade de Deus
review: Full of action, but no soul.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: In its cinematic approach, though, the film is as slick as any Hollywood thriller, directed by Fernando Meirelles with visual flourishes - jazzy editing, lurid colors, crackling sound effects - that dilute the impact of what might have been an indelible cautionary tale.

title: Cidade de Deus
review: Undeniably powerful, but also rather numbing.

title: Star Wars
review: An exhilarating update of "Flash Gordon," very much in the same half-jokey, half-earnest mood, but backed by special effects that, for once, really work and are intelligently integrated with the story.

title: Star Wars
review: If I were asked to say with certainty which movies will still be widely known a century or two from now, I would list "2001,'' "The Wizard of Oz,'' Keaton and Chaplin, Astaire and Rogers, and probably "Casablanca'' ... and "Star Wars,'' for sure.

title: Star Wars
review: Like all great craftsmen, Lucas has managed to fashion this material in a manner that not only honors the original sources, but makes it uniquely his own. Hacks rip off other movies; artists synthesize and pay homage to their inspirations.

title: Star Wars
review: Star Wars, set “a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away,” is the most exciting picture to be released this year — exciting as theater and exciting as cinema. It is the most visually awesome such work to appear since “2001: A Space Odyssey,” yet is intriguingly human in its scope and boundaries.

title: Star Wars
review: A marvelous child of Star Wars technology, the advanced sound design makes a celebratory re-viewing of George Lucas' legendary, 20-year-old space opera a thrilling experience. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars
review: A magnificent film. George Lucas set out to make the biggest possible adventure fantasy out of his memories of serials and older action epics, and he succeeded brilliantly.

title: Star Wars
review: Star Wars brought back for a new generation many of the most attractive elements of studio-era moviemaking, and it did so in breathless anthology form. For some young filmgoers this film acted as a doorway to the glory of the movies.

title: Star Wars
review: Let's discuss those extra four minutes for a second, shall we? I found them incredibly distracting. [Special Edition]

title: Star Wars
review: Everyone treats his material with the proper combination of solemnity and good humor that avoids condescension. One of Mr. Lucas's particular achievements is the manner in which he is able to recall the tackiness of the old comic strips and serials he loves without making a movie that is, itself, tacky.

title: Star Wars
review: Still packs an entertaining punch with its blend of old-movie formulas, new-age philosophies, and video-game visuals. A small amount of new material, added for the 20th-anniversary reissue, is fun to look for but doesn't make much difference to the story or its impact. [Special Edition]

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: A mesmerizing thriller that will grip audiences from first scene to last.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: The interplay between Starling and Lector as they share an indefinable, dark understanding gives the film its unforgettable and unsettling power. [14 February 1991, Daily Notebook, p.E1]

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: The superbly crafted suspense thriller…slams you like a sudden blast of bone-chilling, pulse-pounding terror.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: A movie with this kind of haunting power comes along only once every decade or so. [20 February 1991, Life, p.11D]

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: Hopkins plays the cannibalistic doctor with a quiet, controlled erudition, lacing his performance with moments of black humor. His Lecter is a sort of satanic Sherlock Holmes whose spasms of violence are all the more terrifying because they erupt from beneath such an intelligent and refined mask.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: A smart, restrained entertainment, it doesn't splash around in blood and hysteria. It doesn't have to.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: It has been a good long while since I have felt the presence of Evil so manifestly demonstrated as in the first appearance of Anthony Hopkins in The Silence of the Lambs.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: An accomplished, effective, grisly, and exceptionally sick slasher film that I can't with any conscience recommend, because the purposes to which it places its considerable ingenuity are ultimately rather foul.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: Demme's pacing is tight throughout, marred only by some low-angle close-ups of the cannibal that are right out of old Vincent Price thrillers. [Feb 18, 1991]

title: The Silence of the Lambs
review: Billed as one of the most frightening, depraved films ever made. Would that it were so. Instead, this is a case of much ado about nothing. [15 February 1991, Friday, p.C]

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: It's one of those ageless movies, like "Casablanca" or "The Third Man," that improves with age. Some movies, even good ones, should only be seen once. When we know how they turn out, they've surrendered their mystery and appeal. Other movies can be viewed an indefinite number of times. Like great music, they improve with familiarity. It's a Wonderful Life falls in the second category.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: This couldn't be other than a Capra picture, the humanness of its story the dominant factor at every turn of situation. His direction of the individual characterizations delivered is also distinctively his, and the performances, from the starring roles of James Stewart and Donna Reed down to the smallest bit, are magnificent. When Capra is at his best, no one can top him.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: The film is gripping enough simply with the telling of George's lifestory. A genuine American classic.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: Whether you view this film in the middle of the summer or at Christmas, Capra's greatest film represents one of the most transcendent and joyful experiences any movie-lover can hope for.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: Although peppered with colourful, sharply drawn characters, this is Stewart's movie, instantly loveable as a small town dreamer who sacrifices everything for others. His journey to despair and back warms the cockles like little else. Enjoy it in a cinema so you can sob among others.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: The inspirational, thoroughly festive ending is guaranteed to bring tears to the eyes.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: Frank Capra and James Stewart, in returning to films after long years in uniform, endow the pic with its most telling contributions. Herewith, Stewart touches the thespic peak of his career. He hasn’t lost a whit of his erstwhile boyish personality (when called to turn it on) and further shows a maturity and depth he seems recently to have acquired.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: The film is too sprawling in extent, too noisy as to background music and voices and much too obvious in the application of its social significance notes. But while it isn’t the best picture to come out of Hollywood this year, nor is it Capra’s masterpiece, it tells a good story and its conclusion has a heart-warming effect on the audience.

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: Without overlooking It’s a Wonderful Life‘s lapses into populist bathos, it’s necessary to rescue the Frank Capra film from its status as an untouchable American “classic.”

title: It's a Wonderful Life
review: Indeed, the weakness of this picture, from this reviewer's point of view, is the sentimentality of it—its illusory concept of life. Mr. Capra's nice people are charming, his small town is a quite beguiling place and his pattern for solving problems is most optimistic and facile. But somehow they all resemble theatrical attitudes rather than average realities. And Mr. Capra's "turkey dinners" philosophy, while emotionally gratifying, doesn't fill the hungry paunch.

title: La vita è bella
review: Benigni, with great help from young Cantarini, has crafted a work of such complexity that you may find both your brain and your heart simply overloaded. Which, of course, is the rarely achieved goal of all art.

title: La vita è bella
review: Its unique message about laughing in the face of evil clearly reveals that life is beautiful.

title: La vita è bella
review: Benigni effectively creates a situation in which comedy is courage. And he draws from this an unpretentious, enormously likable film that plays with history both seriously and mischievously. Piety has no place here, nor do tears until the final reel. Life is Beautiful plays by its own rules

title: La vita è bella
review: The concept is not so much nihilistic as it is realistic, and the fact that Benigni has made such fine distinctions so powerfully clear is amazing and moving.

title: La vita è bella
review: While most reviewers will accuse it of sentimentality (a charge that is justified), audiences, who don't feel the need to appear rigorous and tough-minded all the time, will flock to it in droves.

title: La vita è bella
review: Starts out as sentimental whimsy and ends as sentimental kitsch.

title: La vita è bella
review: Benigni sets out to do the impossible.

title: La vita è bella
review: Has good intentions, but its exaggerated celebration of quick-witted improvisation ultimately trivializes the human and historical horrors evoked by the story.

title: La vita è bella
review: The indifference of the proceedings and the hero's slapstick behavior to the everyday realities of the camps borders on the nauseating.

title: La vita è bella
review: Benigni's movie made me want to throw up.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: A visual masterpiece about a scared little girl's breathtaking journey of self-discovery. All of the fun is getting there.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: Yet its visual surrealism, identity-bending and strong social/ecological message make it as much an allegory as a fable.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: Turns everything we know about the contemporary world on its head, and substitutes it with one in which spirits, monsters, magicians and animals mix it up in a carnival of energy, good humor and freewheeling illusion.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: Probably like nothing you've ever seen before. In a cool world, it would be guaranteed not only the Best Animated Feature Oscar, but Best Picture as well.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: Serenely stunning.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: Wondrously strange and just plain wonderful.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: A Japanese cross between "Alice in Wonderland" and "The Wizard of Oz" -- is such a landmark in animation that labeling it a masterpiece almost seems inadequate.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: It will disturb you as much as thrill you, make you wonder whether the boundaries between life and death, reality and fantasy, imagination and insanity are ever what they appear to be.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: A very nutty fruitcake, Spirited Away is characterized by wonderfully detailed animation, packed with incident and populated by all manner of comic creatures.

title: Sen to Chihiro no kamikakushi
review: It's a movie full of bewitching images and timeless fun and beauty.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: An overwhelming experience.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: A war film that, entirely aware of its genre's conventions, transcends them as it transcends the simplistic moralities that inform its predecessors, to take the high, morally haunting ground.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Spectacular, wrenching masterpiece that unflinchingly documents the random horror, the grisly spectacle and the ugliness of war.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: The effect is riveting and frightening. You feel you are under siege with the combatants.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: A magnificent piece of movie-making.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: A bitter, bloody masterpiece with adrenalized emotions and hyper-realized images, this is perhaps as close to battle as any sane human being should ever hope to tread.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: The movie's greatest strength lies in phenomenal performances that reach from the leads right down to the smallest supporting roles.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: If Steven Spielberg's emotional intelligence matched his visual genius, his honorably flawed new film might qualify for one of the greatest-ever American WWII movies.

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Steven Spielberg's new film begins as a monumental epic; then it diminishes; and, by its finish, is baffling. [August 24, 1998]

title: Saving Private Ryan
review: Nothing that suggests an independent vision, unless you count seeing more limbs blown off than usual.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: The Usual Suspects is an ironic, bang-up thriller about the wages of crime. A terrific cast of exciting actors socks over this absorbingly complicated yarn that's been spun in a seductively slick fashion by director Bryan Singer.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: This one's done right. Here's an intelligent movie with no special effects. You have to pay close attention, to listen hard to its cross-fires of dialogue.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: Dense, ironic and thoroughly engrossing caper melodrama.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: The Usual Suspects is an accomplished synthesis of noir elements and, as such, is an entertaining entry to the genre.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: Byrne is a stand-up poet the way some actors are stand-up comics. His innate depth prompts The Usual Suspects to transcend its own cleverness--and this is the movie's smartest, least predictable surprise.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: This thriller is like a game of life-and-death chess, with quick double-crosses and wild gambits.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: I liked this film better the second time around.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: Dense with plot intricacies, thick with atmosphere, and packed with showy roles for a hip ensemble.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: Self-consciously bleak.

title: The Usual Suspects
review: To the degree that you will want to see this movie, it will be because of the surprise, and so I will say no more, except to say that the "solution," when it comes, solves little - unless there is really little to solve, which is also a possibility.

title: Léon
review: Ah, monsieur, you can lead a Frenchman to the Big Apple, but you can't make him a New Yorker -- and that's exactly what makes The Professional so fascinating.

title: Léon
review: Oldman is the least inhibited actor of his generation, and as this deranged detective, he keeps absolutely nothing in reserve.

title: Léon
review: Few action films can claim such complexities without conceding the bang-bang stuff that brings in the big money.

title: Léon
review: Besson's visuals are, as always, vibrant and decidedly European. He fills the frames with odd-angled shots and alarming riots of color that catch you off-balance.

title: Léon
review: With some surprisingly strong character interaction, there's a lot to like about this movie, at least for those willing to look beyond all the bloodshed.

title: Léon
review: This is a Cuisinart of a movie, mixing familiar yet disparate ingredients, making something odd, possibly distasteful, undeniably arresting out of them. [5 Dec 1994, p. 93]

title: Léon
review: Besson has a natural gift for plunging into drama with a charged-up visual style.

title: Léon
review: Takes its viewers on a bouncing high-wire act between intense violence and sugar-sweet tenderness, with some light-hearted comedy along the way.

title: Léon
review: The sheer oddness of the New York world constructed for this film--where cops and crooks are literally interchangeable, and Oldman and Danny Aiello are stranded in roles that pick over the leavings of earlier parts--ultimately seems at once too deranged and too mechanical.

title: Léon
review: Lacks the sexy elan of "La Femme Nikita" and suffers from infinitely worse culture shock. [18 Nov 1994, p.C18]

title: The Green Mile
review: So moving, so memorable, so magically produced, it's going to delight millions of movie fans and sweep the Oscars.

title: The Green Mile
review: Darabont follows King's book fairly closely, allowing the audience to steep itself in the setting and characters slowly, like reading a good novel.

title: The Green Mile
review: There's almost too much there, but the three-hour-plus film permits the kind of detailing that not only brings the storytelling to life, but sometimes persuades us we're breathing to its rhythms.

title: The Green Mile
review: An often pedestrian film, one that never inflates to the epic grandeur to which it aspires or transfers its own emotional trajectory off the screen and into the viewer.

title: The Green Mile
review: Excessive, but I, like Mr. Jingles, can't resist the Christmas-season cheese.

title: The Green Mile
review: A very engrossing movie, the kind that gives shameless manipulation a good name.

title: The Green Mile
review: A film with a counterproductive tendency to take its time...but unassumingly strong, moving performances and Darabont's durable storytelling make it a trip worth taking just the same.

title: The Green Mile
review: Surely a life sentence goes by quicker.

title: The Green Mile
review: Its view of spiritual healing is closer to Spielberg fantasy than religious insight. Still, its good acting and good intentions will be enough to please many viewers.

title: The Green Mile
review: Simply a case of severe overreaching and the illusion that an overstuffed movie is an epic movie.

title: Interstellar
review: An exhilarating slalom through the wormholes of Christopher Nolan’s vast imagination that is at once a science-geek fever dream and a formidable consideration of what makes us human.

title: Interstellar
review: It’s a bold, beautiful cosmic adventure story with a touch of the surreal and the dreamlike, and yet it always feels grounded in its own deadly serious reality.

title: Interstellar
review: Interstellar is Nolan’s best and most brazenly ambitious film to date.

title: Interstellar
review: Brainy and exciting at the same time, Interstellar invalidates the need for mindless Hollywood product. No matter its shortcomings, the movie achieves an impressive balancing act. It turns the mysteries of the universe into a cinematic playground, but for every profound or visually arresting moment, it also encourages you to to think.

title: Interstellar
review: I was moved by Interstellar, and there are stretches where it is as good and as pure as anything Nolan's made. You can feel just how important all of it is to him in every frame of the thing. I don't love all of the film's dramatic choices, though.

title: Interstellar
review: This grandly conceived and executed epic tries to give equal weight to intimate human emotions and speculation about the cosmos, with mixed results, but is never less than engrossing, and sometimes more than that.

title: Interstellar
review: Nolan reaches for the stars in spectacular fashion, delivering a mesmerising sci-fi epic that, despite a testing running time and few too many flights of fancy, is grounded by an on-form McConaughey.

title: Interstellar
review: It’s a glorious spectacle, but a slight drama, with few characters and too-rare flashes of humour. It wants to awe us into submission, to concede our insignificance in the face of such grand-scale art. It achieves that with ease. Yet on his way to making an epic, Nolan forgot to let us have fun.

title: Interstellar
review: For much of the film, Nolan (who co-wrote with his brother Jonathan) seems to be unafraid to allow this big-budget extravaganza to tell a story that's about pain and loss and melancholy and sacrifice. Until it's not that anymore, and Interstellar becomes thuddingly prosaic.

title: Interstellar
review: Promising outer-space majesty and deep-thought topics like some modern variation on Stanley Kubrick's “2001: A Space Odyssey,” Interstellar instead plays like a confused mix of daringly unique space-travel footage like you’ve never seen and droningly familiar emotional and plot beats that you’ve seen all too many times before.

title: Psycho
review: What makes Psycho immortal, when so many films are already half-forgotten as we leave the theater, is that it connects directly with our fears: Our fears that we might impulsively commit a crime, our fears of the police, our fears of becoming the victim of a madman, and of course our fears of disappointing our mothers.

title: Psycho
review: Hitchcock's mischievous genius for audience manipulation is everywhere: in the noirish angularity of the cinematography, in his use of Bernard Herrmann's stabbing string score, in the ornithological imagery that creates a bizarre sense of preying and being preyed upon.

title: Psycho
review: Felt in the full impact of a theatrical screening (with the pleasure of seeing patrons reflexively kick or stiffen at the sight of Miles startled by her mirrored reflection), its power is not just that of a showman’s calibrated scare machine, but of a somber fugue on the trapped 20th-century creatures who inhabit its world, clawing but never budging an inch.

title: Psycho
review: Timeless classic. Superb performances and the infamous shower scene make this the perfect nightmare.

title: Psycho
review: Psycho, in its dark and sordid extravagance, remains utterly contemporary, in its subject as well as in its production.

title: Psycho
review: The obvious thing to say is that Hitch has done it again; that the suspense of his picture builds up slowly but surely to an almost unbearable pitch of excitement. Psycho is a murder mystery. It isn’t Hitchcock’s usual terrifier, a shocker of the nervous system; it’s a mind-teaser.

title: Psycho
review: Perkins gives a remarkably effective in-a-dream kind of performance as the possessed young man. Others play it straight, with equal competence.

title: Psycho
review: Psycho is a brilliant excursion into fear that pushes many of our primal buttons, but it lacks the story and character complexity of Vertigo and Rear Window.

title: Psycho
review: The consequence in his denouement falls quite flat for us. But the acting is fair. Mr. Perkins and Miss Leigh perform with verve, and Vera Miles, John Gavin, and Martin Balsam do well enough in other roles.

title: Psycho
review: What is offered instead is merely gruesome. The trail leads to a sagging, swamp-view motel and to one of the messiest, most nau seating murders ever filmed. At close range, the camera watches every twitch, gurgle, convulsion and hemorrhage in the process by which a living human becomes a corpse...The nightmare that follows is expertly gothic, but the nausea never disappears.

title: American History X
review: Feels as true as a documentary, as painful as a blow to the heart.

title: American History X
review: Jolting, superbly acted film.

title: American History X
review: A true achievement -- no matter who eventually wants to take, or deny, credit for its creation.

title: American History X
review: An inflated yet gut-slugging film.

title: American History X
review: While this movie is sometimes overbaked, it is the first major studio release in a while to engross wall-to-wall.

title: American History X
review: The movie can't explain as much as it wants to about what makes (and unmakes) a skinhead, but it carries us a fair distance.

title: American History X
review: Trenchant and visceral, American History X may not be perfect, but it's a darn sight better than good.

title: American History X
review: For all its surface verisimilitude and for all its focus on a problem that couldn't be more current, this film can't manage to feel more than sporadically real.

title: American History X
review: As a visit to a world and a way of life most of us will never experience, American History X is vivid, and it feels honest. At the very least, it's not typical.

title: American History X
review: A mess of a film.

title: Casablanca
review: The dialogue is so spare and cynical it has not grown old-fashioned. Much of the emotional effect of Casablanca is achieved by indirection; as we leave the theater, we are absolutely convinced that the only thing keeping the world from going crazy is that the problems of three little people do after all amount to more than a hill of beans.

title: Casablanca
review: Much more fun than its stuffy "Greatest Film Ever Made" tag suggests, with a literate script, stylish direction, a great song and cinema's most romantic couple in Bogie and Bergman.

title: Casablanca
review: Casablanca accomplishes that which only a truly great film can: enveloping the viewer in the story, forging an unbreakable link with the characters, and only letting go with the end credits.

title: Casablanca
review: The film has a peculiar magic to it, and because of its pace the richness of its sense of detail often goes unnoticed.

title: Casablanca
review: Seventy years on, this great romantic noir is still grippingly powerful: a movie made at a time when it was far from clear the Nazis were going to lose.

title: Casablanca
review: Despite the fact that the fortunate turn or military events has removed the city of Casablanca, in French Morocco, from the Vichyfrance sphere and has thus in one respect dated the film, the combination of fine performances, engrossing story and neat direction make that easily forgotten. Film should be a solid moneymaker everywhere.

title: Casablanca
review: The most familiar movie in the world is still fresh; it has so many little busy corners to nestle in... Casablanca is the most sociable, the most companionable film ever made. Life as an endless party.

title: Casablanca
review: There are some of the very finest character actors that Warner Brothers could muster and a rich, detailed screenplay studded with an indecent number of sparklingly quotable lines. It is a movie to play again, and again.

title: Casablanca
review: Casablanca was filmed in the safety of the Warner Bros. lot, but the cast of immigrants and exiles who had fled the Third Reich conveyed their visceral fear. While the future was uncertain, the resolute characters of this exquisite wartime drama found peace through love and resistance.

title: Casablanca
review: Here is a drama that lifts you right out of your seat.

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: An additional treat is seeing Hollywood good guy Henry Fonda playing one of the nastiest curs in the West. Once Upon a Time in the West is one of the great films in cinema history. (8/30/2000 Review)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Leone brought back a masterpiece, a film that expands his baroque, cartoonish style into genuine grandeur, weaving dozens of thematic variations and narrative arabesques around a classical western foundation myth.(Review of Original Release)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Sergio Leone's masterpiece. In Once Upon a Time in the West, Leone pulls together all the themes, characterizations, visuals, humor, and musical experiments of the three "Dollars" films and comes up with a true epic western. It is a stunning, operatic film of breadth, detail, and stature that deserves to be considered among the greatest westerns ever made. (Review of Original Release)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: It’s probably unwise to come to Leone looking for too much in the way of feminism. Instead, Once Upon a Time in the West offers quintessential examples of the things he was better known for, including another blustery Ennio Morricone score. Visually, he mostly vacillates between extreme close-ups of intense faces and vast widescreen compositions, a technique that is lurching but also luridly beautiful.

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Akira Kurosawa once said that Toshiro Mifune could give him in three feet of film the emotion any other actor would take 10 to deliver, but in a single flash of Fonda's electric turquoise orbs, Leone (Kurosawa's first and sincerest flatterer-imitator) managed to say as much about John Ford, the devil, and the corruptions of the Way Out Western world as the genre ever would.

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Henry Fonda and Jason Robards relish each screen minute as the heavies, and Charles Bronson plays Clint Eastwood's 'man with no name' role. (Review of Original Release)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Good fun, especially if you like Leone's way of savoring the last morsel of every scene. (Review of Original Release)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: The biggest, longest, most expensive Leone Western to date, and, in many ways, the most absurd... Granting the fact that it is quite bad, Once Upon the Time in the West is almost always interesting, wobbling, as it does, between being an epic lampoon and a serious hommage to the men who created the dreams of Leone's childhood. (Review of Original Release)

title: Once Upon a Time in the West
review: Alas, the big screen also magnifies the problems with Once Upon a Time in the West. Specifically, Leone’s insistence on style trumped the need for substance. The film is basically a B-Western stretched an agonizing 165 minutes.

title: The Pianist
review: Polanski, himself a survivor of Nazi-occupied Poland, has created a near-masterpiece.

title: The Pianist
review: There are three Poles in The Pianist -- Szpilman, Polanski, and Frederic Chopin. Of the three, fittingly, Chopin speaks the loudest.

title: The Pianist
review: The result is a movie, and Cannes Palme d'Or winner, of riveting power and sadness, a great match of film and filmmaker -- and star, too.

title: The Pianist
review: The results are masterful, admirably unsentimental, and never boring, if also a little stodgy.

title: The Pianist
review: This powerful, precision-made movie offers hope as well -- an act of kindness from a German officer that saves the pianist’s life, the music that sustains his soul.

title: The Pianist
review: Never before has a fiction film so clearly and to such devastating effect laid out the calculation of the Nazi machinery of death and its irrationality.

title: The Pianist
review: Szpilman takes to performing sonatas in thin air, eyes closed, those jittery fingers stroking nothing but air. It's a wonderful moment in a wonderful, ghastly film, and one of the most moving arguments for the redemptive powers of art ever made.

title: The Pianist
review: Polanski's film is an unqualified success both dramatically and artistically.

title: The Pianist
review: To name only one of its predecessors -- for me, the towering one -- doesn't "Schindler's List" do everything that Polanski achieves and more?

title: The Pianist
review: Through Brody's remarkably controlled, self-effacing performance, Polanski succeeds in making his hero an invisible man, but the sights he conjures are surprisingly artless and ordinary, familiar from a dozen other Holocaust dramas. Among the casualties in The Pianist is a great director's imagination.

title: Modern Times
review: Chaplin's sentimental politics and peerless comic invention dovetailed more perfectly in this film than in any other he made.

title: Modern Times
review: An ungainly masterpiece, but Chaplin's ungainliness is something one can grow fond of.

title: Modern Times
review: Charlie Chaplin finally got around to acknowledging the 20th century in this 1936 film, which substitutes machine-age gags for the fading Victoriana of his other work. Consequently, it's the coldest of his major features, though no less brilliant for it.

title: Modern Times
review: Remains Chaplin's most sustained burlesque of authority.

title: The Intouchables
review: Enjoy this movie for what it is - the kind of motion picture that can cause Champaign-like giddiness - and don't obsess over how true-to-life this work of fiction is.

title: The Intouchables
review: Let me come clean right now and tell you that I enjoyed The Intouchables quite a bit. If you're looking for a lightweight summer change of pace, with just a smidgen of Continental flair, here it is.

title: The Intouchables
review: The power dynamic may charm the French, but it's likely to push the cringe buttons of local moviegoers in Obama's post-"The Green Mile America." Apart from the wince-inducing moments, The Intouchables is often a pleasant buddy picture.

title: The Intouchables
review: Actually, The Intouchables isn't bad - its merely shameless, but at least it's overtly so.

title: The Intouchables
review: Sy and Cluzet give their parts more conviction than they deserve, even when the former is forced to re-enact the falsetto-singing-in-the-bubblebath bit from Pretty Woman. But even their energy can't revive a corpse this dead.

title: The Intouchables
review: Corny, calculating and commercial...Their slickly executed culture-clash character piece is stuffed chock full of hard-knock life lessons that owe much more to the conventions of the screen than the tough realities of social deprivation and of the severely handicapped.

title: The Intouchables
review: Cluzet and Sy nonetheless make for ingratiating foils; the extended opening sequence in which the duo outwits a pair of cops like a hell-raising Laurel and Hardy could be a stellar short comedy if it weren't married to the deadly self-serious shtick that follows.

title: The Intouchables
review: A cheeky dream-drama about the friendship between a rich, white quadriplegic and a penurious black job-seeker, the premise of The Intouchables alone nearly renders analysis redundant.

title: The Intouchables
review: Though never known for their subtlety, French co-helmers/scripters Eric Toledano and Olivier Nakache have never delivered a film as offensive as "Untouchable," which flings about the kind of Uncle Tom racism one hopes has permanently exited American screens.

title: The Intouchables
review: The plot becomes disastrously condescending: the black man, who's crude, sexy, and a great dancer, liberates the frozen white man. The handsome Omar Sy jumps all over the place, and he's blunt and grating. Francois Cluzet acts with his eyebrows, his nose, his forehead. It's an admirable performance, but the movie is an embarrassment. [28 May 2012, p.78]

title: The Departed
review: A new American crime classic from the legendary Martin Scorsese, whose talent shines here on its highest beams.

title: The Departed
review: A ferociously entertaining film.

title: The Departed
review: The Departed is Scorsese's most purely enjoyable movie in years. But it's not for the faint of heart. It's rude, bleak, violent and defiantly un-PC. But if you doubt that it's also OK to laugh throughout this rat's nest of paranoia, deceit and bloodshed, keep your eyes on the final frames. Scorsese's parting shot is an uncharacteristic, but well-earned, wink.

title: The Departed
review: The original film was gritty and entertaining ("Infernal Affairs"); the new version is a masterpiece - the best effort Scorsese has brought to the screen since "Goodfellas."

title: The Departed
review: A triumphant revisiting of territory in which Scorsese is an unchallenged master -- the crime drama.

title: The Departed
review: The very title The Departed suggests a James Joycean take on Irish-Catholic sentiment when, of course, this story is anything but: It's Scorsesean, and he's in full bloom.

title: The Departed
review: This reworking of a popular Hong Kong picture pulses with energy, tangy dialogue and crackling performances from a fine cast.

title: The Departed
review: The movie works smashingly, especially if you haven't seen its Hong Kong counterpart and haven't a clue what's coming. But for all its snap, crackle, and pop, it's nowhere near as galvanic emotionally.

title: The Departed
review: Back to the streets and with a stellar cast, Martin Scorsese proves once again that he's the master of urban storytelling -- and of thrillingly violent filmmaking.

title: The Departed
review: Neither a debacle nor a bore, The Departed works but only up to a point, and never emotionally--even if the director does contrive to supply his version of a happy ending.

title: Back to the Future
